titleStmt.title: Fault-Tolerant Consensus Tracking Control for Linear Multiagent Systems Under Switching Directed Network

affiliation.orgName: Provincial Key Laboratory of the Theory and Computation of Complex Systems
College of Information Science and Engineering
State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation of Process Industries

analytic.title: Fault-Tolerant Consensus Tracking Control for Linear Multiagent Systems Under Switching Directed Network

biblStruct.note: received October 7, 2018; revised January 30, 2019; accepted February 12, 2019.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, for linear leader-follower networks with multiple heterogeneous actuator faults, including partial loss of effectiveness fault and actuator bias fault, a cooperative faulttolerant control (CFTC) approach is developed. Assume that the interaction network topology among all nodes is a switching directed graph. To address the difficulty of designing the distributed compensation control laws under the time-varying asymmetrical network structure, a novel distributed-referenceobserver-based fault-tolerant tracking control approach is established, under which the global tracking errors are proved to be asymptotically convergent in the presence of actuator failures. First, by constructing a group of distributed reference observers based on neighborhood state information, all followers can estimate the leader's state trajectories directly. Second, a decentralized adaptive fault-tolerant tracking controller via local estimation is designed to achieve the global synchronization. Furthermore, the reliable coordination problem under switching directed topology with intermittent communications is solved by utilizing the presented CFTC approach. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed coordination control protocol is illustrated by its applications to a networked aircraft system.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE COORDINATION problem of multiagent systems (MASs) is inspired by naturally occurring phenomena. In nature, the collective behavior of animal groups (such as flocking of birds, swarming of fishes, etc.) has shown that all individuals can make up a single entity to perform a cluster behavior by means of communications and distributed decisions [1]- [3]. In engineering practice, the cooperative control problem of distributed agent networks has attracted a considerable amount of attention, where distributed subsystems can be applied to perform complex coordination tasks with intergroup cooperation, such as formation coordination of aircrafts/robots, distributed energy resources in microgrids, and so on [4]- [8].

It is well recognized that the consensus (leaderless consensus) and consensus tracking (leader-following consensus) are two typical problems in multiagent coordination, where all subsystems aim to reach an agreement only using local interactions [9]- [17]. In the above two cases, the reliable communication network is an important key to transmitting information among neighborhood subsystems. However, due to an increasing number of agent subsystems and unreliable interconnections, including channel failures, environmental, and sensor limitations, the individual faults (subsystem failures) and communication faults (network failures) are frequent and have undesirable impacts on global coordination behavior. In recent years, increasing effort has been studying cooperative fault-tolerant control (CFTC) for MASs subject to subsystem faults and unliable interactions, and major results concerning the CFTC problem can be found in [18]- [33].

In general, all these works mentioned above are classified into two types. On the one hand, the distributed consensus protocols have been presented to deal with network failures (such as switching topology or communication constraints) for linear and nonlinear MASs in [18]- [21]. Note that the proposed static protocols in the above results cannot compensate unknown time-varying faults in node dynamics directly. On the other hand, the distributed fault-tolerant consensus problems of MASs subject to individual node faults are addressed in [22]- [32]. Based on distributed control reconfiguration strategy or adaptive fault compensation technique, the CFTC algorithms for agent networks are designed by utilizing neighborhood information. But these works are commonly assumed that the interaction network is a fixed and connected topology. Very recently, based on fault diagnosis mechanism and fault accommodation strategy, [33] provides 2168-2267 c 2019 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

a reliable consensus protocol for switching directed agent networks, which is dependent on a priori knowledge of failure estimation using fault detection and isolation. In our previous work [34] and [35], by utilizing distributed adaptive updated algorithm and topology-dependent multiple Lyapunov functions approach, the adaptive reliable coordination algorithms are designed for linear MASs with actuator faults, uncertainties, and undirected switching network. For the case in which the interaction network governed by a switching directed topology, however, these consensus protocols cannot be applied, because the compensated gain design of agent subsystems cannot be decoupled from the asymmetrical Laplacian matrix structure directly. Therefore, the design of CFTC protocol for switching directed agent networks is more difficult than the design for undirected networks, and so becomes a challenging issue.

Inspired by the aforementioned discussions, this paper addresses the fault-tolerant consensus tracking control problem for linear MASs with a time-varying network and actuator failures. In consensus algorithm design, a new constructive CFTC methodology including two steps is designed to tackle the asymptotically consensus tracking problem of leaderfollowing MASs. The main contributions of this paper are fourfold.

First, the fault-tolerant consensus tracking control of linear MASs under a directed switching network is studied, and a more general condition for the time-varying communication topology containing some nonidentical directed spanning trees is assumed. Compared with [33], this paper aims to design an adaptive CFTC algorithm subject to unknown actuator faults, including partial loss of effectiveness (PLOE) and time-varying bias faults, and compensate for faulted agent networks without fault diagnosis mechanism.

Second, a novel CFTC control approach is set up by exploiting the distributed reference observers (DROs) and the decentralized adaptive fault-tolerant tracking controllers, which constructs a two-step design to overcome the decoupling problem between the local controller gain and asymmetrical topology structure. Note that the DROs enable all followers to estimate the state trajectories of leader containing unknown input. Also, the decentralized fault-tolerant controllers not only compensate the subsystem failures but also achieve global tracking objective.

Third, by combining topology-dependent multiple Lyapunov functions method with adaptive failures compensation strategy, the rigorous convergence analysis (see Theorems 1 and 2) is established to prove that the states of all followers can asymptotically track desired trajectories by employing the proposed CFTC algorithm. Furthermore, unlike the existing results about adaptive coordination control for directed agent networks with fixed topology in [23], [24], [26], and [31], where the consensus tracking errors converge to a small residual set, the switching directed communication network is considered as well as the asymptotically consensus tracking goal is ensured in this paper.

Finally, we construct an augmented CFTC protocol to handle the intermittent communications in the switching directed interconnection networks. It is worth noting that the presented design conditions are dependent on the network structure property and topology-dependent average dwell time (TDADT).

The remaining sections of this paper are organized as follows. An MAS model and considered problem formulation are given in Section II. The CFTC algorithm for MASs is presented in Section III. Section IV applies the theoretical results to an example on a group of F-18 aircrafts. Finally, the conclusions are drawn in Section V.

div.head: A. Preliminaries
div.p: The n-dimensional Euclidean space is denoted as R n ;

• represents the Euclidean norm of vectors or matrices. diag{D 1 , . . . , D n } represents a block-diagonal matrix with matrices D i . Let X ⊗ Y denote the Kronecker product of two matrices X and Y of appropriate dimensions. λ max (X) and λ min (X) denote the maximum eigenvalue and the minimum one of a symmetric real matrix X, respectively. 1 m×n ∈ R m×n represents the vector with all entries being one.
A time-varying directed graph or digraph G σ (t) = (V, E σ (t) , A σ (t) ), contains a vertex set V = {1, 2, . . . , N}, an edge set E σ (t) = V × V, and an adjacency matrix
div.formula: A σ (t) = [a ij (t)] ∈ R N×N .
div.p: Here, a switching signal σ (t) is defined by σ (t) : [0, +∞) → P with P being an index set for all possible graphs. Suppose that there exists an infinite sequence of uniformly bounded nonoverlapping time intervals [t h , t h+1 ), t 0 = 0, h ∈ N, and denote τ h as a dwell time satisfying (t) and l ij (t) = -a ij (t), i = j. Moreover, a directed graph contains a directed spanning tree if there exists a root node, such that the root has directed paths to all other nodes.
div.formula: t h+1 -t h ≥ τ h . Let L σ (t) = [l ij (t)] ∈ R N×N be a time-varying Laplacian matrix of G σ (t) , with l ii (t) = N j=1,j =i a ij
div.p: Definition 1 [36]: A nonsingular real square matrix Q is called an M-matrix if all of its off-diagonal elements are nonpositive, and each of its eigenvalues has positive real part. Moreover, matrix Q is called a nonsingular M-matrix if Q is an M-matrix, and its the principal minors are positive.

div.head: B. Problem Statement
div.p: In this paper, we consider a team of N +1 linear agents on a switching digraph G σ (t) composed of one leader indexed with 0 and N followers. The dynamics of the leader are modeled as
and the dynamics of each follower agent are represented by

where x 0 (t), x i (t) ∈ R n and u 0 (t), u i (t) ∈ R n u represent the states and control inputs, respectively. We assume that u 0 (t) is a bounded input signal for leader agent, and (A, B) is stabilizable with the constant matrices A and B. Assumption 1: There exists a positive constant u * , such that u 0 (t) ≤ u * .

In this paper, the communication network of MASs is assumed to be time varying, and then the underlying topology among N + 1 subsystems can be described by a switching digraph G σ (t) . Let L σ (t) denotes the Laplacian matrix associated with G σ (t) , which is defined as follows:
where
div.formula: L 1σ (t) = [l σ (t) 11 , l σ (t) 12 , . . . , l σ (t) 1N ] T ∈ R N×1 and L 2σ (t) = [L σ (t) 2ij ] N×N ∈ R N×N , across the time intervals [t h , t h+1 ), L 1σ (t)
div.p: and L 2σ (t) are the constant matrices, for all h ∈ N.
Assumption 2: For each interval [t h , t h+1 ), h = 1, 2, . . ., the interaction graph G p is fixed and contains a directed spanning tree with agent 0 as the root.

For T > t > 0, we denote t 1 , t 2 , . . . , t N σ (T,0) as the topology switching times on the interval [t, T]. When t ∈ [t h , t h+1 ), σ (t) = p, that is, the pth network topology G p is activated. Then, according to [34], the notion of TDADT is given as follows.

Definition 2 [34]: For any T > t ≥ 0, consider the topology switching signal σ (t) over (t, T), let N p σ (τ 1 , τ 2 ) represent the number of switching of the pth topology over (t, T), and denote T p (τ 2 , τ 1 ) as the total running time of G p . If
div.formula: N p σ (t, T) ≤ N p 0 + T p (t, T) τ ap (4)
div.p: holds for τ ap > 0 and N p 0 > 0, then τ ap is called TDADT. Lemma 1 [10]: Let L be a nonsingular M-matrix, then there exists a positive diagonal matrix
div.formula: = diag(γ 1 , γ 2 , . . . , γ N ) such that L + L T = > 0 and γ = [γ 1 , γ 2 , . . . , γ N ] T = (L T ) -1 1 N .
div.p: The following actuator fault model in follower subsystems is considered:
div.formula: u mF i,k (t) = ρ m i,k u i,k (t) + f m i,k (t), t ≥ t m i,k(5)
div.p: where
div.formula: k = 1, 2, . . . , n u , m = 1, 2, . . . , M, ρ m i,k represents the unknown actuator fault parameter, satisfying 0 < ρ m i,j ≤ ρ m i,j ≤ ρ m i,j ≤ 1, f m i,k (t)
div.p: is an unknown time-varying bounded signal, and t m i,k with index m represents the unknown failure time instant under the mth fault mode (m = 1, 2, . . . , M). Note that the faulty signal u mF i,k (t) in (5) implies the following three cases.
div.formula: ρ m i,j = ρ m i,j = 1 and f m i,k (t) = 0. This indicates the fault- free case. 2) 0 < ρ m i,j ≤ ρ m i,j < 1. This means the PLOE. 3) ρ m i,j = ρ m i,j = 1 and f m i,k (t) = 0. This indicates the bias fault. Let u F i (t) = [u F i,1 (t), u F i,2 (t), . . . , u F i,n u (t)] T , ρ i = diag(ρ i,1 , ρ i,2 , . . . , ρ i,n u ), and f i (t) = [f i,1 (t), f i,2 (t), . . . , f i,n u (t)] T ,
div.p: then, the faulty actuator signal for all possible faulty modes M can be described by
div.formula: u F i (t) = ρ i u i (t) + f i (t), ρ i ∈ ρ 1 i , ρ 2 i , . . . , ρ M i (6
div.p: where
div.formula: ρ m i = diag(ρ m i,1 , ρ m i,2 , . . . , ρ m i,n u ), i = 1, 2, . . .

div.head: , N. Assumption 3:
div.p: The actuator bias fault signals are bounded, that is, there exists an unknown constant, such that f i (t) ≤ f . Remark 1: In the complex distributed architecture of agent networks, the node failures may occur at any time in faulty components of some nodes. Different from the actuator faults, the external disturbances are attributed to the external environment of the practice system. In addition, it is worth mentioning that the sensor faults/noise are aroused by problems of measurement equipments in subsystems. Although the disturbances or sensor faults/noise are not considered in this paper, inspired by [26] and [34], the reliable H ∞ consensus control problem for the switching directed agent networks subject to actuator/sensor faults and disturbances becomes an important issue to be investigated in future work.

Problem: Considered the leader-following MASs consisting of ( 1) and ( 2) under a switching directed network G σ (t) , the control objective here is to develop a cooperative fault-tolerant tracking control algorithm, such that the consensus tracking errors converge to zero asymptotically even in the presence of actuator faults, that is, lim t→∞ x i (t)x 0 (t) = 0, for i = 1, 2, . . . , N.

Remark 2: This paper aims to investigate adaptive faulttolerant coordination of linear MASs under switching directed topology. In contrast, the adaptive fault-tolerant consensus algorithms given in [25], [27], [28], [30], [34], and [35] are only applicable to the case of undirected topology. Compared with [33], the design of reliable control strategy for agent networks does not need fault diagnosis mechanism. It should be pointed out the main difficulty here is how to solve the decoupling problem between subsystem controller design with asymmetrical network structure, which is a challenging issue.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, we construct the DRO for each follower only using neighborhood information, which ensures that all follower subsystems can estimate the state trajectories of leader exactly. Then, by utilizing the estimation from DROs, the decentralized fault-tolerant controller is designed via adaptive failure accommodation technique. In the following, Fig. 1 shows a block diagram of the control design architecture.

div.head: A. Distributed Reference Observer Design
div.p: In this part, a DRO for each follower subsystem is given to estimate the leader's trajectories. According to Assumption 2, one can see that L 2p (p ∈ P) are nonsingular M-matrices. Then, by using Lemma 1, it follows that:
div.formula: p L 2p + L T 2p p = p > 0, for all p ∈ P (7

This completes the proof.

div.head: B. Decentralized Fault-Tolerant Controller Design
div.p: In this section, we will design the decentralized adaptive fault-tolerant controller u i (t) for all follower subsystems such that all followers' state vector x i (t) asymptotically tracks reference state xi (t).
First, let δ i (t) = x i (t) -xi (t) denote the local tracking error for each subsystem. Following this procedure, for the ith follower, we proposed the adaptive controller in the form
div.formula: u i (t) = β1,i (t)K 1 δ i (t) + K 2,i (t) (21
div.p: where K 1 = -B T P 1 represents the feedback gain matrix with P 1 > 0 satisfying the following inequality:
div.formula: P 1 A + A T P 1 -2P 1 BB T P 1 + Q < 0.(22)
div.p: In ( 21), we choose K 2,i (t) as
div.formula: K 2,i (t) = - β2 2,i (t)B T P 1 δ i (t) B T P 1 δ i (t) β2,i (t) + η i (t) (23
div.p: where η i (t) ∈ R + is any positive uniform continuous and bounded function satisfying lim t→∞ t t 0 η i (τ )dτ ≤ ηi < ∞ with a positive bounded constant ηi . In addition, β1,i (t) and β2,i (t) are determined by the following adaptive updating laws:
div.formula: β1,i (t) = -ε 1,i η i (t) β1,i (t) + 2ε 1,i B T Pδ i (t) 2 β2,i (t) = -ε 2,i η i (t) β2,i (t) + 2ε 2,i B T Pδ i (t) (24
div.p: where ε 1,i and ε 2,i are given positive constants. Note that β1,i (t) and β2,i (t) represent the estimates of β 1,i and β 2,i , respectively, which are defined as follows:
Denote β1,i (t) = β1,i (t) -β 1,i and β2,i (t) = β2,i (t) -β 2,i , then the closed-loop error systems can be obtained as follows:
div.formula: δi (t) = Aδ i (t) + Bρ i β1,i (t)K 1 δ i (t) + B ρ i K 2,i (t) + f i (t) -v i (t) . (26
div.p: Then, the following theorem is given to characterize the asymptotic convergence of the local tracking errors δ i (t). Theorem 2: Suppose Assumption 3 holds, then the decentralized fault-tolerant controller (21) with adaptive law (24) guarantees that all signals in closed-loop system (26) are globally bounded, and the tracking errors δ i (t) asymptotically converge to zero, that is, lim t→∞ x i (t) -xi (t) = 0, i = 1, 2, . . . , N.
Proof: First, we choose the following Lyapunov-Krasovskii function:
div.formula: V(t) = N i=1 V i (t) = N i=1 δ T i (t)P 1 δ i (t) + 1 2 N i=1 i ε -1 1,i β2 1,i (t) + ε -1 2,i β2 2,i (t) . (27
div.p: Using ( 27), ( 24) and ( 26) yield
div.formula: V(t) ≤ N i=1 δ T i (t) P 1 A + A T P 1 δ i (t) -2 i β1,i (t) B T P 1 δ i (t) 2 + 2δ T i (t)P 1 B ρ i K 2,i (t) + f i (t) -v i (t) - N i=1 i β1,i η i (t) β1,i + β 1,i -2 B T Pδ i (t) 2 - N i=1 i β2,i η i (t) β2,i + β 2,i -2 B T Pδ i (t) . Notice that 2δ T i (t)P 1 B(ρ i K 2,i (t) + f i (t) -v i (t)) ≤ 2 i β 2,i • B T P 1 δ i (t) - ([2 β2 2,i (t) i B T P 1 δ i (t) 2 ]/ [ B T P 1 δ i (t) β2,i (t) + η i (t)]
div.p: ), where i is a positive constant satisfying Bρ i B T ≥ i BB T . Hence,
div.formula: V(t) ≤ N i=1 δ T i (t) P 1 A + A T P 1 δ i (t) -2 i β 1,i B T P 1 δ i (t) 2 -2 i β1,i (t) B T P 1 δ i (t) 2 + 2 i β1,i B T Px i (t) 2 - 2 β2 2,i (t) i B T P 1 δ i (t) 2 B T P 1 δ i (t) β2,i (t) + η i (t) + 2 i β 2,i B T P 1 δ i (t) + 2 i β2,i B T P βi (t) - N i=1 i η i β2 1,i + β1,i β 1,i + β2 2,i + β2,i β 2,i .
div.p: According to the inequality (22) and 0 ≤ (ab/[a + b]) ≤ a, (∀a, b > 0), it is derived that
div.formula: V(t) ≤ N i=1 -δ T i (t)Qδ i (t) + 2 i η i + i η i 4 (β 2 1,i + β 2 2,i ) ≤ -λ min (Q) N i=1 δ i (t) 2 + N i=1 η i κ i where κ i = i (2 + [β 2 1,i /4] + [β 2 2,i /4]). Denote δi (t) = [δ T i (t) βT
div.p: 1,i (t), and βT 2,i (t)] T . Then, from (27), one can know that there exists a scalar ϕ i > 0 so that 0 ≤ ϕ i δi (t) ≤ V i ( δi (t)), and then, we know that 0
div.formula: ≤ N i=1 ϕ i δi (t) ≤ N i=1 V i ( δi (t)) ≤ V(t 0 ) + N i=1 κ i ηi , which means that δ i (t), β1,i (t), and β2,i (t) are bounded. Also, from V(t) = δ T i (t)P 1 δi (t)+ i (ε -1 1,i β1,i β1,i + ε -1 2,i β2,i β2,i ), we obtain δ i (t) is also bounded, which implies δ i (t) is uniformly continuous. Moreover, it is easy to derived that lim t→∞ t t 0 λ min (Q) N i=1 δ i (τ ) 2 dτ ≤ V(t 0 ) + N i=1 κ i ηi . (28)
div.p: Therefore, applying the Barbalats lemma to (28) yields lim t→∞ x i (t) -xi (t) = 0, which completes the proof.

Remark 3: Different from the existing literature on distributed FTC protocols in [19], [23]- [28], and [31]- [34], this paper presents three distinct features. First of all, the switching directed topology condition is considered, which is a more general condition in practical application. Second, the DRO scheme is introduced to overcome the main difficulty in the first step, and then the adaptive accommodation controller is designed for each follower node to either compensate individual actuator faults or achieve global synchronization. Third, the asymptotically consensus tracking performance of the linear MASs is ensured by combining the TDADT method, adaptive compensated technique, and algebraic graph theory.

Remark 4: When the communication network has asymmetrical topology structure, the directly adaptive consensus protocol designs [7], [23], [24], [26], [31] cannot completely eliminate the influence of leader's input and subsystem failures in the stability analysis. In fact, the coupling terms of nondiagonal elements in the above results are considered as the auxiliary positive terms, which are only handled by using robust control strategy. As a result, the proposed adaptive consensus control methods in these works only ensure that the global tracking errors are uniformly ultimately bounded (UUB). In this paper, Theorems 1 and 2 ensure that the asymptotically consensus tracking can be achieved, by employing the two-step CFTC algorithm designed in Section III. Thus, the proposed control protocol obviously extends the existing results in the literature.

div.head: C. CFTC Design Under Intermittent Communication Constraints
div.p: As is well known, the communication environment among agent subsystems is not perfect all the time. In practice, the interactions between subsystem with its neighbors may be continuous in some disconnected time intervals, which may be effected by the limitations sensing ranges, link failures, cyber attacks, etc. In this section, we consider the case that the underlying network is a switching directed topology with intermittent communications. We will show that the reliable coordination tracking objective under the above constraints is achieved by using the proposed CFTC algorithm. According to [21] and [35], for t ∈ I , we assume that the intermittent failures occur in dynamic directed networks; in other words, all agents can only change information with neighbors when t ∈ C , where

and there exist the nonoverlapping subintervals [t 0 q , t 1 q ), . . . , [t q , t +1 q ), . . . , [t l q -1 q , t l q q ) in each interval [t q , t q+1 ), with t 0 q = t q , t l q q = t q+1 = t 0 q+1 , and t q ( = 0, 1, . . . , l q ) are the topology switching time instants. Then, we design the DRO for agent i as follows:
div.formula: ẋi (t) = Ax i (t) + Bv i (t), if t ∈ C Ax i (t), if t ∈ I (30
div.p: where v i (t) is given in (9). Thus, the reference estimation error x(t) can be described as
div.formula: ẋi (t) = ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ I N ⊗ A + c 0 L σ (t) ⊗ BF 1 x(t) + (I N ⊗ B) •(F 2 (t) -1 N ⊗ u 0 (t)), if t ∈ C (I N ⊗ A)x(t) -(I N ⊗ Bu 0 (t)), if t ∈ I . (31
div.p: Based on the above presentation, the following lemma can be obtained. Theorem 3: Under Assumptions 1 and 2, the reference estimation error system (31) is UUB if for given scalars α m > 0, c > 0, and ξ 1 > ξ m > 0, there exists a symmetric matrix W > 0 such that (14) and the following inequalities hold: (34) for h ∈ N + . Moreover, the observer gain is given by
div.formula: AW + WA T -ξ m W < 0 (32

) p∈P α p - ln μ p τ ap T p t 1 h , t h+1 -ln b 0 a 0 > ξ 1 t 1 h -t h
F 1 = -B T W -1 .
div.p: Proof: This part is given in the Appendix.
In the following, we state a result which can solve the CFTC problem for linear MASs (1), ( 2) with switching directed intermittent communications.

Theorem 4: Under Assumptions 1-3, suppose that the DRO designed in (30), and the decentralized fault-tolerant controller (21) developed in Section III-B with adaptive law (24) are applied to the cooperative systems (1), (2) under directed network. Then, all the state tracking error signals in the resulting closed-loop error system (26) are UUB even in the cases of subsystem actuator faults and intermittent communications.
Proof: It is similar to the proof of Theorem 2 and omitted.

Remark 5: Note that the unknown actuator faults, including PLOE and time-varying actuator bias of follower subsystems are considered in this paper. As discussed in [25], [34], and [37] the proposed adaptive reliable consensus protocol in this paper can be also applied to deal with the general actuator fault model, which cover the cases of PLOE, outage, bias, and stuck, if an assumption of actuator redundancy for agent subsystems holds, that is, rank
div.formula: [Bρ i ] = rank[B].

div.head: IV. SIMULATION EXAMPLE
div.p: In this section, the proposed method is applied to a simulation example of the coordination control problem for a team of F-18 aircrafts [38]. We consider an MAS consisting of one leader and four followers. The dynamics of each subsystem is given as follows: First, we select c = 2 and α m = 3.5. Then, according to Algorithm 1, the solutions of LMIs ( 14) and (22) In simulation, the initial conditions and the parameters given as follows:
div.formula: ẋi1 (t) ẋi2 (t) = -
div.p: Moreover, the considered actuator faulty modes are assumed that: 1) all subsystems operate in the normal mode before 6 s; 2) at t = 6 s, the first actuator has loss effectiveness of 90% in the second subsystem; 3) at t = 13 s, the second actuator in Agent 1 has bias at f 1,2 (t) = 5 + 4 sin(0.25t); and 4) at t = 15.5 s, two actuators in the third subsystem have loss effectiveness of 85% and 80%, respectively.

Figs. 4-7 show that the response curves of reference state estimations and subsystem states of Agent i, i = 1, 2, 3, 4 with comparisons to the states of leader subsystem (Agent 0), and Fig. 8 exhibits the profiles of estimates of controller parameters β1,i (t) and β2,i (t) for all follower subsystems. It is clear that the states of each follower subsystem can asymptotically track desired trajectories as well as all parameter estimations in the closed-loop network are bounded, which means the asymptotically consensus tracking performance can be ensured. Therefore, the simulation results will illustrate the proposed consensus strategy in this paper. IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CYBERNETICS Fig. 7. State and estimation trajectories of Agent 4. Fig. 8. Profiles of the updating parameters β1,i (t) and β2,i (t), i = 1, 2, 3, 4.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, a novel distributed reliable consensus tracking protocol of linear agent networks with switching directed topology and unknown actuator faults has been presented by exploiting the two-step control algorithm, which includes DROs and decentralized fault-tolerant controllers. Within this framework, the asymptotic convergence of consensus tracking errors has been proved by combining Lyapunov stable theory, algebraic graph theory, and switching system theory. Moreover, the developed CFTC algorithm is designed to solve the consensus tracking problem for directed agent networks subject to intermittent communication faults. Finally, the effectiveness of the presented CFTC algorithm has been verified by simulation results. In our future work, the proposed cooperative control algorithm design is to be investigated in the coordination control problem of MASs in practical scenario, such as external disturbances, sensor faults/noise, communication delays or errors, and so on.

where ν 0 and 0 are two positive constants. Finally, we define T f = (1/ 0 ) ln([b 0 ν 0 x(t 0 ) 2 ]/[a 0 z * ]). From (40), it can be seen that the reference estimation error can enter the set D = {x(t)| x(t) < z * } within the interval [t 0 , t 0 + T f ]. In addition, for all x(t) ∈ D, we have x(t) ≤ √ (b 0 z * /a 0 ). Therefore, one can conclude that x(t) exponentially converge to the following compact set {x(t)| x(t) < √ (b 0 z * /a 0 )}. This completes the proof.
